page.title: 02GEOGRAPHY : THE WALL AREA.
page.content: The area is on the eastern side of the South Staffordshire plateau and lies within a few kilometers of Lichfield whilst the Birmingham and Black Country conurbation is a little further afield. Geologically the district consists of a mixture of Bunter sandstones and clays with some glacial drift and these have favoured agriculture. Relatively fertile soil and proximity to urban centres plus freely available water held in the Bunter sandstone and gravel beds have resulted in an emphasis on intensive market gardening and cereal production. The water is extracted for use in irrigation via boreholes and submersible pumps. There is some dairy farming. The land, which is undulating has no major drainage but the main flow to the north is to the Trent system.
